lines.text: [Carbo's abusive riding tactics have killed his horse]
Bury him.
What with?
Your god-damned hands!
[to reporter]
See he does it. You see to it!
What he said, is it that important?
Must be, he said it twice.
Hey, British! Drink to the winner.
[Carbo throws Norfolk a bottle of whiskey]
Thank you. I haven't really won the race yet, however.
How far is it to town?
Don't know. Never seem to have made it.
Well, you don't know much.
Huh?
I said you don't know much.
Mister, I don't know a damned thing about nothin'... but I ain't the one who's lost.
We're big news everywhere!
[reads telegram]
Adding $250 to purse and will headline winner in my Wild West show. Signed Buffalo Bill Cody."
Hey, wasn't he the fastest gun in the West?
Only in bed, kiddo.
You certainly have a knack of provoking a man to violence.
All I said was she...
It was the way you said it - like it was an insult.
Hell, yeah, when a woman does it for money...
A man always gets the best of the bargain. Before you take her to bed, she's a thing of beauty. In bed, an angel of mercy. And afterwards, she's a...
Whore!
...a pillow piece.

I've been around a lot of cowhands, one way or another. A cowboy dresses from the top down. The first thing on is his hat. And he undresses from the bottom up. Last thing off... hat. Oh, and another thing - to be a cowpuncher, that don't mean you actually got to go around punching them, you know.

God, what ain't I tried. Pony express rider, Overland Stage driver, lawman, gambler, riverman, rancher, rodeo hand, barman, spittoon man... old man. Never much to remember. Of course, there ain't much to forget, either. Nobody's got much use for an old man. I can't blame 'em much. That's why I'm going to win this here newspaper race. When I cross the finish line, I get to be a big man. Top man. A man to remember.
Hey, old man, thought sure you cashed it in.
Not 'til I'm back in Oklahoma.
I'd rather be in Hell than Oklahoma!
Every man to his own country.
I've never saw a man who could hold his liquor like a bottle.
Ever prospected? Ever hit pay dirt? I've dug for gold, silver, lead, mercury. I've dug more holes than a whole regiment of gophers. I ain't never dug a decent day's wages yet.
All this hardware... I ain't never been in a gunfight.
Killing a man don't prove you're a man.
Rosie, how many times you been married?
Eleven. Ten without a preacher or license.
Well, did you love any of 'em?
Oh, all of 'em! Every one of 'em! The good and the bad. It's a shame to waste all that prime beef on a guy serving three to five in a prison. Do you keep in touch?
Oh, he's kind of a lousy letter writer.
A lousy bank robber, too.
No family?
Him
[indicates his horse]

. Oh, you know saddle tramps. They sign on, drive the beef a thousand miles, make your mark, draw your pay and move on to the next ranch. Another roundup and another drive. Hired... fired... and move on.
Well, it's never bothered me none.
No, me neither when I was thirty years lighter.
For a family who don't know a jackass from a mule, you sure know a lot about the West.
We don't have to know about it. We, ah, we own it.
[first lines]
I heard your newspaper is running an honest race.
You heard right, Mr. Gebhardt.
Who the hell handicapped this owlhead as the favorite?
The smart money!
That's what we come to get.
Whiskey for me and beer for my horse!
Two important regulations. Rule One...
Win!

You'll be issued a compass and a map for each leg of the race. On it, you will find the safest route. You don't need to take it. You do have to make every checkpoint. Miss one, you're disqualified - out of the race. Any questions? Jump off time - six in the morning.
[Matthews ignores Carbo's challenge for a gunfight]
You done right. A boy lookin' for a reputation is the most dangerous thing alive.
It certainly wasn't worth dyin' for.
What is?
Just like old times.
Yeah. You start trouble and I start bleedin'.
[when the enraged Carbo starts after Matthews when the older man's back is turned, Mister intervenes with a drawn pistol]
My eyes ain't as good as his'n. I might miss and then you'd be dead and I'd be out of the race... for abusin' a dumb animal. Bad for you... worse for me.
Mister? How do you like it, Mister?
Without conversation.
You know, I'm un-American.
What's that?
Well, I don't know exactly, except if you're not the best, the first and the greatest - if you don't win, then you're not American.
And how was the shorter route?

[chuckles]
Longer.
We came out of the jungle and there it was - San Juan Hill. The Spanish guns lookin' right down our throat, the sharpshooters pickin' us off and we just charged right up that hill!
[starts to ride off, but returns]

That's not the way it happened at all. It wasn't anything like it was in San Antoine where we did our trainin'. That's where I ran into Luke and a lot of other men from every other country who wanted to be Roughriders. Bakers and barbers and Congressman, cattlemen, ballplayers, farmers and porters... cowboys. No, we didn't rough ride up that hill, 'cause we didn't have any horses. We didn't charge up there, either. We crawled up there on our scared bellies. There was only one horse and one rider - that was Colonel Teddy. He went chargin' up that damn hill and they shot his glasses off. He put on another pair and they nipped him in the elbow, and he said, "Follow me!" And we did, 'cause we was too damned ashamed not to.
The people some people marry. I wasn't worth her spit.
To the West!
Awesome and inspiring.
violent, treacherous. Every prairie dog hole is a gold mine, every molehill is a mountain, every creek is a river and everybody you meet is a liar.
When you call me that smile, stranger.
The people some people marry.
The father of your father, he was truly Mexicano?
Nah
But you are simpatico?

[rides away]
Had a toothache once.
I want you to tell me the story of your life. Just skip everything up till the last fifteen minutes.
That sonofabitch tried to kill me.
Oh, he couldn't'a tried very hard.

[handing Rosie money for prostitutes]
Two of the best for two of the best.

[hugging Rosie]
I forgot how good a bad woman feels.
Flattery and money will get you anything.

[after the Mexican has killed a snake about to strike]
Jesus!
He is generous today.

[holding up heroin tablets]
You ever try this?
Mister, I've tried everything but confession.
How much does Parker pay you? Fifty dollars a month? Sixty? Win this race and you could have three years' salary!

Mister, did you ever see a horse run himself to death just to please the man on his back? What's the horse get out of it? Cracked bones? Colic? See his picture in the paper? Horse doesn't give a damn who wins a race. Me neither.

[to young toughs]
Don't you know Sam Clayton? Defender of dumb animals? Damsels in distress? Champion of lost causes?
How ya' been?
Fine, till *you* showed up.

[showing the newspaper to the horse]
Well, you're in the papers... and I'm in the shithouse.

[referring to the motorcycle]
How do you start it, how do you make it go, and how do you stop it?

[counting out money from a roll]
You're gonna need moving money.

[tending to his horse]
Who says I'm movin'?
Stayin' takes even more... costs ten dollars just to get drunk.
I'm gonna stay sober.
Fifteen dollars for a hot bath.
Guess I just won't bathe.
Thirty dollars for an all-night woman.
[Clayton stops, pauses, sticks out his hand for the money]

[after hitting Carbo on the side of the head]
Hurts, don't it?
Aw,who wants the easy life?
*I* do.
Who won the Gans - Nelson fight?
Gans, by knockout in the 42nd round. Greatest fight I ever saw.

[to Norfolk, referring to a previous conversation]
Gans! In the 42nd round!

[after receiving a foal from Clayton]
Do I have to pay somethin'?
Yeah... don't ever treat her bad.
